A block of mass \(m_1\) rests motionless on an inclined plane. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between the block and the plane are \(\mu_s\) and \(\mu_k\). A massless string attached to one end of the block passes over a fixed pulley, around a second freely suspended pulley, and is finally attached to a fixed support. The left hand part of the string is parallel to the plane. The sections of the string coming off the suspended pulley are vertical. The pulleys are frictionless and massless, but a block of mass \(m_2\) is hung from the second pulley. Gravity acts downward.
Part a: What is the maximum value of the mass that block 2 can have without block 1 beginning to slip upward along the incline?
\(m_{2,max}= 2m_1(sin \theta - \mu_s cos \theta)\)
\(m_{2,max}= 2m_1(sin \theta + \mu_s cos \theta)\)
\(m_{2,max}= 2m_1(cos \theta - \mu_s sin \theta)\)
\(m_{2,max}= 2m_1(cos \theta +\mu_s sin \theta)\)
\(m_{2,max}= m_1(sin \theta - \mu_s cos \theta)\)
\(m_{2,max}= m_1(sin \theta + \mu_s cos \theta)\)
Part b: What is the relationship between the acceleration of block 1, \(a_1\), and the acceleration of block 2, \(a_2\)?
\(a_1=a_2\)
\(a_1=-a_2\)
\(a_1=2a_2\)
\(a_1=a_2/2\)
\(a_1=-2a_2\)
\(a_1=-a_2/2\)
Part c: What is the acceleration of block 1?
\(a_1=2g(m_2-2m_1sin\theta-2\mu_km_1cos\theta)/(4m_1+m_2)\)
\(a_1=2g(m_2-2m_1cos\theta-2\mu_km_1sin\theta)/(2m_1+m_2)\)
\(a_1=2g(m_2-2m_1sin\theta+2\mu_km_1cos\theta)/(2m_1+m_2)\)
\(a_1=2g(m_2-2m_1sin\theta-2\mu_km_1cos\theta)/(4m_1+m_2)\)
\(a_1=2g(m_2+2m_1sin\theta-2\mu_km_1cos\theta)/(2m_1+m_2)\)
\(a_1=g(m_2+2m_1sin\theta-2\mu_km_1cos\theta)/(4m_1+m_2)\)
